unnormalised: Planning a trip to India can be exciting, but figuring out where to stay and how to get there can be a bit of a headache. My own recent adventure started with booking a charming little guesthouse in Udaipur. The initial booking confirmation just stated "Near City Palace, Udaipur," which wasn't exactly helpful when the auto-rickshaw driver asked for a specific address at 6 AM. Turns out, "Near City Palace" meant 200 meters down a narrow lane from the main entrance, at 15, Jagdish Temple Street, Udaipur, Rajasthan, 313001.

unnormalised: The next challenge came when I had to arrange transportation from Udaipur to Jodhpur. The bus ticket simply mentioned “Udaipur Central Bus Stand” but neglected to specify which entrance. There are actually 3! After some frantic inquiries, I discovered my bus was departing from Gate No. 2, near the tea stall, facing the road towards Shastri Circle. Next time, I’ll definitely pre-pone my arrival to account for such uncertainties.

unnormalised: Then there was my stay in Goa. I’d booked a cottage through an online portal, the address listed as "Near Baga Beach, Goa." Classic Goa! What they conveniently forgot was the actual number and lane: House No. 7/A, Saunta Vaddo, Baga, Bardez, Goa, 403516. I ended up wandering around for an hour, asking locals, before finally stumbling upon it. The saving grace was the delicious seafood at a nearby shack, "Lila Cafe, Baga," which everyone seemed to know.

unnormalised: My train journey from Mumbai to Delhi was another adventure in address decoding. My friend had booked me a room at a hotel close to the New Delhi Railway Station. The address read "Paharganj, Near Railway Station." This translated to Main Bazaar, Paharganj, New Delhi, Delhi 110055 - a chaotic, bustling lane filled with shops and other hotels making it difficult to find "Hotel Paradise", my destination.

unnormalised: One thing I learned is to always verify the complete address before arriving at a location. Contacting the hotel or guesthouse directly is the best way to avoid any confusion or delays. "Near" isn't specific enough when you're navigating the crowded streets of an Indian city, especially when you're carrying a heavy suitcase and the monsoon season is in full swing!

unnormalised: Ultimately, these experiences taught me that a little preparation goes a long way. A detailed address – including the house number, street name, city, state, and postal code (like 560001 for Bangalore or 400001 for Mumbai) – can save you a lot of time and frustration. Happy travels, and may your addresses always be clear and your journeys smooth!
